== Who I am ==

My name is Mehmet Basaran, and I have been a member of the Ubuntu Kernel Team since 04/2024. I received bachelors degree from TOBB University computer engineering department in 2011 and masters from Bilkent University in 2014.
Before joining Canonical, I was working on a Phd (which I dropped out of) on parallel/high-performance computing. Afterwards I worked on a commercial POSIX compliant RTOS for 5 years.

== My Ubuntu story ==

I have started using Ubuntu in the early years of university which was around 2007 (Ubuntu 6.06) to get some school work done. I remember installing windows afterwards ubuntu which overwrote bootloader. I didn't know how to recover that so I had to re-install in the correct order to make it work.
Slowly ubuntu became my daily driver (it was much easier to code here because of gcc + valgrind combo). It became my only OS afterwards.

=== My involvement ===

As a part of stable squad, I am working on SRU release cycles. Usually, my responsibilities include;

* cranking kernels,
* inspecting test results for regressions,
* organization / communication / helping out the rest of the team to close off past cycles.

Additionally, I work with TNT team on a new kernel test result viewing tool. Which will make it easier to inspect RT results and open up some possibilities for the future.

=== Things I could do better ===

* I can review mailing list patches faster (I can learn more about the generic concepts in linux kernel and create a qemu setup for testing).
* I can learn more about SWM (Software Workflow Manager), Snaps, SRU cycle details.
* I can communicate more effectively / efficiently.
* I can ask more questions and be more active in the SRU training mattermost channel. 
* I can improve my knowledge of debian packaging.
* I can Manage my time better.
* I can create test setup to recreate regressions and learn linux kernel debugging techniques to solve problems.

== Plans for the future ==
* learn to review ML faster.
* learn more about SWM, Snaps, and SRU cycle details.
* learn more about debian packaging.
